title: 114_s2134
content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals receive information on application requirements and a list of participating entities. The pilot program offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, a degree in a health-related field, and experience in delivering healthcare services. The pilot program offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, a degree in a health-related field, and experience in delivering healthcare services. The program focuses on military training for disease identification, evaluation, treatment, and prevention. It will run for five years with a selection of at least 250 participants by the Secretary. The pilot program gives priority to individuals who participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program or agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration at a Department medical facility in a specific community. The pilot program prioritizes individuals in a community designated as medically underserved and with a high percentage of veterans. The Secretary will provide educational assistance, including scholarships, for individuals in a pilot program to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. Existing programs like the Department of Veterans Affairs Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program will be utilized for this purpose. The Secretary will provide scholarships for individuals in a pilot program to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. Participants must agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration. Participants in the pilot program must work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. Participants in the pilot program must work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration for a period of three years or as determined by the Secretary. Failure to fulfill the obligated service will result in liability to the United States. Participants in the pilot program must work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period. Failure to complete the obligated service will result in liability to the United States for the amount paid or payable to the individual, adjusted based on the days served. The individual must fulfill the obligated service period or face liability. Mentors will be available for participants in the pilot program at Veterans Health Administration facilities. The Secretary will partner with at least 15 institutions offering a master's degree program in physician assistant. The pilot program requires institutions offering accredited master's degree programs in physician assistant studies to guarantee seats for eligible participants and provide necessary support. The pilot program requires institutions to guarantee seats for eligible participants in physician assistant studies and provide support. Other institutions offering similar accredited programs and government assistance programs are also included. The pilot program under the Department of Labor's Veterans' Employment and Training Service aims to market and advertise to veterans and Armed Forces members. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Veterans Health Administration for program administration. The pilot program overseen by a physician assistant veteran employed by the Department involves recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, and assisting them in applying to a master's degree program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant veteran employed by the Department, is responsible for overseeing the pilot program, recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, and assisting them in applying to a master's degree program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention oversees the pilot program, coordinates candidate recruitment, and assists participants in applying to a master's degree program. They are also responsible for identifying employment positions and mentors for participants in the program. The recruiter in the pilot program may be employed at a medical center of the Department. They report to the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention and work on national recruiting strategic plans for physician assistants within the Department. An administrative assistant at level GS-6 or equivalent assists with administrative duties in the Office of Physician Assistant Services to ensure effective operations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report on a pilot program to Congress. The report will assess the effectiveness of the program in improving the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants and achieving its goals. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report on a pilot program to Congress. The report will identify necessary modifications to meet the goals of improving the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants and addressing the shortage of physician assistants employed by the Department. The pilot program report must include an assessment of its potential as a model for other Department programs and specify that $8,000,000 of funding should come from existing Department of Veterans Affairs appropriations. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. Directors of medical centers will be held accountable for not utilizing the educational assistance effectively. The Department of Veterans Affairs will ensure the availability of the Education Debt Reduction Program for participants in the pilot program to fill vacant physician assistant positions, aiming to advance employee education and improve recruitment and retention. The Department of Veterans Affairs will promote the Education Debt Reduction Program for physician assistant positions by including it in vacancy announcements and informing applicants of their eligibility. They will also monitor compliance with educational assistance programs to ensure full utilization. Additionally, programs will be created to support these initiatives. Creating programs to encourage Department of Veterans Affairs employees to apply to accredited physician assistant programs. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out this section. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF PAY GRADES FOR PHYSICIAN ASSISTANTS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS AND REQUIREMENT TO PROVIDE COMPETITIVE PAY. (a) Establishment of Pay Grades.--Section 7404(b) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include pay grades for physician assistants and the requirement to provide competitive pay. The Physician Assistant Schedule is being updated to include competitive pay for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs. The National Strategic Plan will be implemented by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a national strategic plan for the retention and recruitment of physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, ensuring competitive pay compared to the private sector. A report on this plan must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment. The House of Representatives will receive a report on the implementation of the national strategic plan for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs.
